reviewText: What a terrific movie!  I had forgotten how wonderful this movie was until we purchased it for our daughters.  The music is stunning, and the voices are perfectly fit for the characters they serve.  Especially noteworthy is Louis Prima as "King Louie".  The score is beautiful as well, using much haunting alto flute playing.  A masterpiece that deserves a place on everyone's video shelf!
If I had to pick my favorite Disney movie, it would be this one.  Why, love the music!!  Too bad it is a typical Disney DVD with no extras.  Would have loved them.

This wonderful, delightful, joyful animated story of a young mancube that was orphaned by Shere khan as a baby. He was saved by Bagheera and brought  to a wolf family and was raised as one of there own. About nine years later  the man hating Shere Khan retured to that part of the jungle. The wolf clan  decided that it would be best that Mowgli (the mancube) went back to the  man village. Bagheera voluntered to bring him back. They encountered the  sly snake that hypnotyze his pray, the army elephants that never forget,  the wild orangatang king that lives in the temple, the beatle like  voltuers, and you can't forget the great one Baloo who has a free loving  spirit.

Yet another in Disney's self proclaimed Masterpiece editions, The Jungle Book is a lot of fun but not one of Disney's best.  Watch this video for some great songs and wonderful characters but please excuse the flimsy  story which is all but cancelled out in the film's final scene.  Still, the  movement captured by the Disney animators, especially in the case of  Bagheera, is a marvel to watch.  With all these great characters (Baloo,  Shere Kahn, King Louie wonderfully voiced by Louis Prima) and memorable  songs (The Bear Neccesities) it's unfortunate that the story couldn't also  have been worthwhile.  Still, no one will resist adding this to their  clam-shell collection before it's gone...for now at least.

The feature-length cartoons Disney continues to produce are fine films, but nowhere near as good as classics like The Jungle Book.  Unburdened by the modern-day Disney habit of giving every film a heavy family-friendly  moral message, the Jungle Book is just 100% pure fun, with a cool hero  (Mowgli), entertaining friends (especially the bear Baloo) and some great  villainous characters (most memorably Shere Khan the tiger).  This movie  was made years before Phil Collins or Elton John were drafted in as cartoon  soundtrack composers, and the songs are just awesome - "The Bare  Necessities", "I Wanna Be Like You" and Kaa the snake's  hissed encouragement to "Trust in Me".  Get this DVD while you  can!

This movie is more than just another Disney masterpiece.  The Jungle Book is a great tale of friendship and adventure.  Although almost every animated feature that was created during Walt Disney's life is a classic,  this one in particular holds a special place in the heart of many men (and  now thanks to video and DVD, boys) who saw it while growing up.  There  isn't a boy alive who can see this movie and not want to be Mowgli.  What a  life it would be to live in the jungle, with friends like Baloo and  Bagheera.  It is every young boys dream to be so free.
That is not to say  that only boys will love this movie.  As with all Disney films, this one  will be enjoyed by all members of the family, young and old.  I saw it  growing up, and never forgot my memories of the movie, and the days  afterward, singing the songs and dreaming of adventure.
The music in  The Jungle Book is some of the best in any Disney movie.  "The Bare  Necessities" is simply one of the best songs ever.  Add in the fantastic  animation and the characters that come to life (who wouldn't believe a bear  could sing after seeing this?), and you have one of the many classic Disney  stories.
Starring the voices of Disney regulars Phil Harris and Sterling  Holloway, as well as Sebastian Cabot (Mr. French, to those of my  generation) and many others, this movie is too good to not buy.
Get a  copy of this DVD before Disney removes it for another generation.  It is  the best that Disney has to offer.
By far, this is my favorite Disney & what does it is the music.  Some Disney films may have characters I love more with the great music, but this one does it.  Well done by the Sherman Brothers.
has a bit of what could erroneously be interpreted as racisim; but is actually a tribute to Louis Amstrong, Toots Theilman, Bichet and others.

Fails the Bechdel test, mostly because there are no female characters at all. Boy lives in the jungle with animals and raised by bears, yet both decides to wear clothes and is able to fashion himself a suitable garment. A bunch of animals that naturally live in different parts of the world inexplicably meet. Orangutans are coded African-American and talk about wanting to be real people. There are big huge cats.

Bought this for the kids.  They've seen the original animated version, which this is not really a substitute for.  It is tempting to compare them because they are the same(ish) story, but I think it is best to look at these movies as separate entities.  At any rate, if you know the story and want to insert some live action shows into the rotation for the kids, this isn't a bad way to go.  It is a little more direct with the violence, so if you're looking to shield your children, skip this and go back to the animated version.  Overall I like it, the CGI was phenomenal and was integrated well.

This brings back the jungle book's amazing story as a child, and i don't think the changes to it effected the overall story, one bit. if anything it dug deeper into the story, not made it any less powerful. you didn't loose anything, and in fact, it really felt like there was a whole story there.  a move done well is rare, especially when i say this. just overall GREAT acting & film.  there could have been a million ways to mess this up, and these guys actually did it right!  props to all who created the special, effects, as well, for they are most definitely  the BEST special effects i have ever seen. Even beets Avitar any day !  also, not too much singing in this one & the songs you do have are actually enjoyable, and are the ones that count!  We simply can't for get "bear necessities"  as even though i'm not a huge fan of singing, i would have thrown a fit if that  one wasn't in there.  there were also very comical moments that you just can't pass up and could watch days on end and not get tired of it...i think it will be stuck in my head forever.
hysterical & tear-wrenching at the same time, a movie you can really fall in love with, and characters presented in the best light!  Even the tiger had a reason to be as mean as he was.  who wouldn't be?  personally, would have liked to see him go after the entire  village, instead of picking on a defenseless runt  that has no say in it.  but then he wouldn't have made that iconic  villain!  the eyes for the tiger and the expression was just amazing; it gave him a true magic about him, as well as the panther.
The wolves actually looked like real wolves;  where perhaps the ear posture and lips wasn't perfect in terms of wolf behavior, it was almost spot-on for when a wolf is defensive.  at one point in the movie, the wolves looked more unsure and scared and worried, when they were actually supposed to be matching a fiercely  growling and a snarling scene.  but if you don't know "wolf  Language" then you wouldn't have known this.  WAY more accurate than twilight, OR beauty & the beat remake. Best wolves yet!  and this is coming from somebody who has studied  a bit of wolf behavior.  keep up the good work humans!
some of my favorite  quotes  and moments were where..."leaf...leaf!...that's mine...Rock!...that's mine....rock...rock...that's mine...rock...that's mine..."
and the "i has ears that has ears...."  one

and who can forget that priceless little moment of when the wolf pup that  only forgets the word "wolf"  in the pledge.  that would have totally been me!!!!

Wow! Just wow. What an amazing and beautifully done live action version of The Jungle Book! I was glued to the UHD TV for the whole time. Not only did it shine, but I was able to view it in 2160p glory. Just gorgeous. I have to say this is one of my favorite Walt Disney movies and now that it is "Live Action" is even better!! I thought the cast did an amazing job with it. The characters did come to life for me and were believable. I will watch this again and again in months ahead. The 3D looks really good here, too. Disney, you did a stellar job on this, so keep 'em coming if they can look like this one!
~ The Musical Score, The Animals and effects were spot on, in my opinion. This has to be one of the very best "Live Action" adaptations so far for Disney!
~ The Menu and Special Features are pretty amazing as well and I loved it all. If you have kids that love this kind of movie, you are going to love it, too!
~ HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

I am old and grey now, but really enjoyed the adaptation of this film.
"The Jungle Book" was one of my favorites as a child.
Raised 4 kids and "own" most "Disney Animated" films on both VHS and DVD (we have watched them "a million times". Parents will know what I mean).
Mowgli was fantastic.
The animation and CG of this old "classic" was wonderful.
In classic Disney style, there is great attention to detail (also a mixture of "Light/Fun" and "Dark/Scary").
There is a scene where Baloo and Bagheera are crossing a river, chasing the monkeys to "King Louie" and the camera "lens" gets splashed with animated water, very cool!
Limbs of trees move with animal weight, animal footprints left as they walk, etc......

I would however be very "cautious" about letting "little ones" watch some of the violent animal scenes in this movie.
It is NOT a "cartoon"!!!
Quote: "Rated PG for some sequences of scary action and peril"!!!!!!!

Most of the movie is delightful and fun.
My only complaint would be that towards the end, with all the "fire", the scenes were so "dark" it was difficult to see some of the detail in the movie.

If you enjoy Disney flicks, I think you will enjoy this one.
Try not to compare it to the "great" original cartoon, there is enough of the original story line to keep you engaged. Naturally, voices are changed/different, King "Kong" Louie was a little "big" (Ha). Let it stand on its own.

Note: Watch the "credits" and enjoy the scenes and music! - (Scarlett Johansson (Kaa), Dr. John, Christopher Walken (King Louie), etc
.
Entertaining film.

All the other reviews are right on target here. This is a visually stunning movie and I will usually balk at total CGI movies. the voice talents are outstanding and the best is the little boy who plays Mowgli. This kid is nothing short of amazing. The directing by Jon Favreau is off the charts, what an eye for detail. I wholeheartedly recommend this movie for young and old but as a caution let me throw this out there. There is one scene that is probably going to be hard on little kids and you should be aware it is between the wolf pack leader and Shere Khan the Tiger. Other than that, love Neel Sethi, the boy and the characters are so real and genuine too. Bill Murray as Baloo is outstanding.

Everyone in the family loves this movie.  We originally got it for our niece, who's 25 years old.  I mean she was 25 when she put it on her Christmas list.

You cant beat the original animated Jungle Book. You just cant and its fair to say that this live action/ CGI mix doesnt try to but simply tries to capture the magic of the story of an orphaned young boy raised by jungle animals but who is led back to mans village for his own proetection. And on that account it succeeds famously well with some set pieces that are just awe inspiring, as is King Louies immensity. This version has some music and some song but it isn't a musical like the original, but the original simply doesnt muster the menace that Mowgli faces at almost every turn as this one manages to depict in a fairly safe but still effective PG rated way. Kaa the monstrous constrictor is bound to generate nightmares but it never actually threatens Mowgli outside of unnerving presence. The vicious Shere Khan is vicious in the way he maintains and utilizes his aggression and threat far far moreso than he is physically vicious. If theres one thing that this film ends up lacking it would be a sense of dread, but suspense is still maintained. This is entirely appropriate for a kids movie and The Jungle Book balances these issues nicely. Kudos to director Jon Favreau for pulling this off.

Jon Faverau's live action remake of a late 60s Disney animated classic (and the last film Walt Disney himself worked on at the time of his death) is an extraordinary masterpiece that is truly remarkable and a lot better than the original 1967 animated film! The cast is great as are the special effects.

It seemed as though Jon Faverau wanted to accomplish the same goal he accomplished with "Elf" in that you feel like you could walk right into this world! He succeeded! You truly feel like you can walk right into the jungles of India in this film!

Plus, I'm super happy this won the Oscar for Best Visual Effects! It truly deserved it and it deserved to be a critically acclaimed monster hit at the box office!

Can't wait for the sequel! Check this adaptation out! A must see and must own film for sure!
I've heard of mixed reactions from friends, but I enjoyed it. People seem to miss the light-heartedness of the original, while I appreciated the tension in this one.

The original Jungle Book is one of my favorite Disney Movies, and I appreciated that although it was a live action performance with CGI animals, it still felt like I was watching a modern adaptation of the original animated movie. The actors chosen to voice the animals were perfect, and the story was entertaining for me and my family. I purchased this around black Friday for a great price, and my son has enjoyed watching the movie several times already. some of the extra scenes not shown in the original animated film were particularly entertaining, and while it wasn't exactly a "musical" like the original was, it still had bits and pieces from the original movie. I love this film, and highly recommend it to anyone looking to add another film to their Disney collection.

Great movie for youngsters and even young adults. It's the story of a young baby abandoned in the jungle, found by a panther and then taken care of an reared by a pack of wolves. Most of the video covers the adventures and dangers encountered while trying to accomplish this, as well as his eventually deciding to stay in the jungle with his wolf family.

The animation in this film is great. I love all of the actors and the voice acting, I mean they really went over the top with the cast. It's just okay for me though and doesn't really allow the actors to shine. You take some of the best actors of all time and take away their visual characteristics and you have a move with great tone, but it's not the same. I wasn't taken with it, the way that other movies move you. I didn't empathize with the characters, one because I knew the story, but also, because it's anthropomorphized to allow the animals to speak, they really left it there. In the original cartoon, the animals acted like people. In this, it was like realistic animals that could talk. Disney has a habit of releasing old films with updated graphics to sell more copies and toys now, and while I think one was a good attempt, it's just okay.

This movie is full of great surprises,with various cameo voice overs, one in particular that had a gangster style approach, which was very amusing. This adaptation takes us on a journey that reaches our hearts and souls. It is sometimes a little scary in places; so not really for the very young but it remains exceptionally beautiful throughout. I did not want the movie to end. see it, you will not be disappointed.

This disk among many recent makes it worth upgrading to the new display technology of OLED, which renders eye-blinking levels of detail and blacks as deep as pitch, not to mention working alongside a dedicated sound system to create a wholly enveloping experience.

Mowgli is such a sweet little boy who is raised by a pack of wolves and a panther (Bagheera) in the big Jungle. I loved the portrayal of family values between man and beast. Little Grey wanting to stay by his big brother's (Mowgli's) side, Grey missing him when Mowgli decided to leave the pack - it was just heartwarming.

Then there is a drought and the truce formed between predator and prey - anyone is allowed to drink from the waterhole without having to watch your back. It is truly amazing.

Then Shere Khan's threats towards Mowgli and the pack - Mowgli leaving with Bagheera, the death of Akhila, Mowgli meeting Baloo and us seeing the most hideous humongous ape - King Louie. Mowgli saving the baby elephant was such a touching scene - he didn't have to do it but he wanted to because he is a sweet kid. I think they found the perfect kid to play the part :)

I just loved watching this movie with my family - it is adventurous, some LOL moments but most of all, it's all about going to great lengths to protect the ones we love.

If you haven't watched it as yet then what are you waiting for???

Brilliant film, beautiful nature, excellent acting, artistic balance, design, color, everything.  However, the last third gets WAY TOO INTENSE
for young sensitive children.  There is a lot of violence, and terrorizing energy. I wouldn't take any child under 11 or 12 to see this.  Perhaps
I'm being too protective, but I was braced (as an adult) for the last third of the movie, protecting myself from the strong visuals and sounds
that pumped adrenalin through my veins.
  I'd show the younger children the earlier cartoon version and let them mature enough to be ready to truly enjoy this one.
  My parents took me to see Fantasia as a toddler and I still remember being terrified.  I saw Wizard of Oz as a young girl, and fell asleep
in the scenes with the witches because I was too afraid.  Why imbed scary memories for your beloved babies?  I am 68 and still become
anxious at those memories and blame my parents for not being sensitive enough to protect me from those scenes.

I was pleasantly surprised with the retelling of the Jungle Book story. The special effects do justice to the movie. I'm usually critical how CGI is overused in movies today, but it gave the talking animals more of a realistic  look. And the jungle scenes  looked realistic and natural. My main criticism is with the young actor playing the orphan. He lacked the ability to convey depth or  emotion. His performance was passable but I think an Indian actor with the correct dialect would have made it more convincing. Also I didn't care for the songs hijacked from the animated version. It just didn't work for me. And of course the word "cool" uttered by the main character sounded silly. I recommend this version, even with the flubs I mentioned. I usually don't sit thru a whole movie these days, but I it kept me involved.

"The Jungle Book", what can I say, it's as ambitious, fun and stunning as you might would imagine it to be. Visual effects, spectacular and some of the best I've ever seen. But at the same time, I felt like this movie benefited greatly from an old-fashioned feel. At many times in the script and personalities of the characters, save for a few lines here and there, this movie felt like a 1960's Disney movie. And that's what makes "Jungle Book" so fun and one of their finest live-action updates so far.

It doesn't make you cry nor does it have a deep story, but then again, neither did the animated movie. I also thought the musical numbers retained from the original weren't exactly well-executed. Overall, I still think "Enchanted" and "Pete's Dragon" are my favorite live-action Disney "fairy tales", but this one isn't too far behind. Definitely one to see with the whole family! :)  4.1 out of 5 stars.

When I learned that Disney was remaking its animated classic "The Jungle Book," my first reaction was simply "why?"  Disney had already created a live-action remake of this movie in the '90s to mixed effect, and I didn't see any reason for them to redo this one.  It seems that live-action remakes are going to be the new thing for Disney's classics, however, what with "Cinderella" and "Maleficent" doing well financially and "Beauty and the Beast" gaining a lot of buzz.  I didn't want to simply hate this movie for being a remake, however, and figured I should give it a chance before writing it off.

I'm very glad I did so -- this updated version of "The Jungle Book" is actually quite gorgeous, with amazing visuals, fantastic voice work by an all-star cast, and a darker but still poignant and exciting story.

"The Jungle Book" follows young Mowgli, a boy literally raised by wolves in the jungles of India.  When the tiger Shere Khan (voiced by Idris Elba) threatens Mowgli's life, the wolves send him away to be returned to the village of Man, accompanied by the panther Bagheera (Ben Kingsley) for protection.  But when disaster strikes and Mowgli and Bagheera are separated, Mowgli ends up encountering other denizens of the jungle -- the hypnotic and dangerous python Kaa (Scarlet Johannsen), the manipulative but easy-going and ultimately friendly bear Baloo (Bill Murray), and the power-hungry mobster-boss ape King Louie (Christopher Walken).  When Shere Khan threatens Mowgli's wolf family, he finds he must choose between safety with Man... or saving his friends and family from the cruelty of Khan, even if it costs him his own life.

This film is gorgeous to look at -- practically everything except Mowgli is CGI, but unlike other mostly-CGI movies (*cough the Star Wars prequels cough*) it sure doesn't look like it.  The animals are fantastically rendered, and manage to emote and speak in a human manner without falling directly into the uncanny valley.  This is especially impressive with both Baloo and King Louie, who retain something of their voice actors' expressions and mannerisms but manage to not look creepy in the process.

The voice work is also impressive, with an all-star cast that never feels jarringly out of place.  Elba is appropriately menacing as Shere Khan, and Walken brings a sinister vibe to this rendition of King Louie, who is far more mobster-boss than jazz-musician in this rendition.  Scarlett Johanssen's role as Kaa was hotly contested and, I admit, a little weird at first, but she does a good job in her role and provides a very memorable moment int he movie.

This story is darker than the original 1967 film, just as a warning -- little kids might be scared by some scenes of destruction and animal violence, though notably there's no blood.  And while it's still far closer to the "in name only" '60s adaptation than the original novel, it still draws from those roots and turns the cartoony tale of the original film into something epic and exciting.  And Mowgli no longer seems like a petulant child being dragged along on an adventure against his will, but a character with real growth and development who ends up making his own choices about his destiny instead of being treated like a prop.  I appreciated this immensely.

If I have any complaints about the movie, it's that it wedges two of the original films' songs in without taking care to make sure they fit.  Baloo's song, "Bare Necessities," is at least somewhat justified, but King Louie's "I Wanna Be Like You" feels like it comes out of nowhere when it pops up.  Given the darker, more realistic tone of this film, the inclusion of the songs feels jarring and weird to me.  (We do get to hear Kaa's number "Trust In Me" as well, albeit over the end credits...)

An epic and exciting remake, with gorgeous visuals and excellent voice work, this film put my doubts to rest and gives me faith that Disney will handle the incoming flood of live-action remakes very well.  I just hope the upcoming remakes of films like "The Lion King," "Mulan," and "Beauty and the Beast" are just as good...  Recommended for children ages 8 and up due to violence and some dark, thematic elements.

I am a life long die hard Disney fan, so I was very curious to see how this story would be told as a live action movie.  I was enthralled in the first couple of minutes and at times was stunned to remember the animals were all CGI - the movie was absolutely stunning with seamless interaction between the only actor (Mowgli) and the special effects animals.  The actors who breathed life into the animals were amazing, they helped each character portray power, elegance or sneakiness as they needed.  I really enjoyed Bill Murray who voices Balou, he can make you fall in love with the silly scheming bear.  This was  great addition to my Disney collection.

Yes, I'm one of those people who often feels that you just can't trump my childhood memories of the "classic original" Disney movies with these new remakes and their over-hyped, fancy computer graphics. I even have a good rant or two concerning the "lack of originality these days".
But honestly? I thought this movie was great. It was beautiful to watch, the characters felt sincere and real, and the story carries you along effortlessly. I even felt that Mowgli's character was improved upon. In the original version he was quite petulant, often complaining about how unfair it was that he had to move away, despite the threat against his life. But in this version, he understood that his presence put his family in danger, and he was much more willing to step up and make sacrifices for their safety. It was emotionally engaging, and I am definitely happy to have seen it. I think you will be too!

The visuals are stunning in this movie!  I like this remake of the Jungle Book.  It was lighthearted, fun, nostalgic, entertaining and well done.  The actors did a great job!  Neel Sethi, played a very convincing Mowgli.

Raksha, the mother wolf, played by Lupita Amondi Nyong'o, was one of my favorite characters.  She brought so much heart and soul to this movie.  I loved watching  her with her wolf cubs.

I loved Bill Murray as Baloo and the bare necessities references.  Between Bill Murray's Baloo and Christopher Walken's King Louie, I was thoroughly entertained and amused!  They were perfect for those roles!

Ben Kingsly was fantastic as Bagheera, the panther, Mowgli's mentor/protector/teacher.  He has that presence, wisdom, and dignity about him.

Scarlett Johansson as Kaa, the python, was entertaining.  I would have loved to see more of Kaa in the movie.

Idris Elba as Shere Khan was fierce and frightening!  You could certainly feel that sense of threat!

Disney has been doing quite well with their live-action movies such as Maleficent and Alice In Wonderland. CGI has gotten so good that it can look absolutely real. This is used to good effect in Disney's "The Jungle Book", a remake of their popular 1967 film. The animation is superb, and the actors who provide voices for the various animals are very well chosen. Ben Kingsley is properly dignified and intellectual as the panther who watches over Mowgli, and Bill Murray is entertaining as the lazy and scheming, but loyal bear. Scarlett Johanssen provides the seductive voice for the python, and Christopher Walken is the voice of the leader of the apes, who rules them like a crime boss. The young boy who plays Mowgli is the only real human to appear on screen, except for a flashback which also briefly shows his father.

The story is a lot darker than the old cartoon version, and we understand why Shere Khan the tiger hates Mowgli so much. The moments when Mowgli is in the clutches of the python or the apes are appropriately exciting and terrifying. There are also a few lighthearted moments, and 3 of the songs from the older version have been updated and show up at least for a verse or two. One scene made me laugh out loud when Mowgli is led into the ruined city to meet the head ape. He notices a pile of rusty objects on the ground and picks up something....I won't spoil it by identifying what it is, but it was a perfect moment.

I attempted to watch this, twice, but couldn't make it through. It comes down to being extremely attached to and fond of the original; I admit to being unable to give the new version a chance. Visually, it is stunning; it just doesn't have the heart of the original. The way they have drastically switched up the characters is disconcerting as well. One example is Kaa being a female. Kaa in the original, so perfectly voiced by Sterling Holloway, has no equal as it is. Switching 'him' to a female?? WHY???

There are certain original films that are so completely perfect, just the way they are, there should be a law against 're-making' them. The Little Mermaid, E.T., The Wizard of Oz, all of The Toy Story films, and certainly The Jungle Book.

Specifically in this "Limited Issue" DVD, you can see the entire 4:3 ratio of the film. It wasn't shot in widescreen, sometimes Disney would produce features in 4:3 and crop the top & bottom for widescreen theaters. The "Platinum Edition" does this widescreen cropping, and it is very noticeable that you're missing imagery from the top & bottom of the film (see attached photo comparison.) I own both editions now, since each has its own enjoyable features, but this is the only version where you can see the entire film.

I have revised my rating to 3 stars from 4... something I've never taken the time or felt the need to in the past. Since I usually never even write movie reviews I'll try to keep it short as this change does at least require an explanation. I, like most others, initially thought the movie had done a very good job of telling the beloved Kipling tale with some much needed new zest and a variety of great voices lending their talents to this wonderful idea of a project. I know that the new little kid deserves a break as it was his first real opportunity to act. AND having to do it to a blue screen surely cannot be easily tackled by a child.
Bottom line is that the animals look great. Murray and Walken step up to deliver the goods. But all the other big names, with maybe the exception of Sir Ben, kinda fell a little flat.
If I were to watch it again for the first time I'd probably give it 4 stars again. But, and here's the kicker, nobody seems to want to be at all critical of the movie's low points. I wanted so badly to give this 5 stars as I had read so many positive reviews that I felt my initial criticisms would have been too harsh. But, having watched the film more than twice now I can honestly say that people are being just a little too kind to this one.
So there you have it. Take it with a grain of salt. But you can't say that at least someone on Amazon didn't speak-up and be a bit more critical than a 6 year old would be.
On a lighter note... go ahead and watch it! Enjoy it!! And make up your own mind in the end. At the very least, it is most certainly worth your time.

Arrgghh, the stereotypes.  Louie?  Please.  That's out of the 1940s noir genre, and that same old old idea is still being cast in the 21st century.  Ragtime music?  Old, dull, bitterly dull.  The wise old Shakespearean English man.  The strength of the pack is the wolf and the strength of the wolf is the pack.  Maybe I'm just too old at age 57 to appreciate another rendition of remakes, but that's a lot of what comes out of the movie industry.  Remake after remake, prequels, sequels.  They are boasted as the most creative people among us, yet they rely on same old themes, same old actors, same old stereotypes, same ol' same ol'.  Yes, the graphics were terrific, and that's one of the reasons I have a 4k screen, but I I still yearn for something new and something creative beyond what computers these days can do.

I am an adult who watched the original Jungle Book although it was up to date with technology the story for adults is rather boring. The young actor in it has no emotion when conveying anger, fear, confusion etc . He looks like the boy from the Jungle book but he is a terrible actor. He often speaks to the animals in a way you can imagine a puppet being there with the visual effects crew saying pretend it's a wolf , tiger etc. It has a few good visual effect moments although I find the animals that are the main characters unrealistic  . It may be good for children who have never seen the original so I added a star to my one star. Louie and the monkeys scene was probably the highlight of the movie with the best visually. My boyfriend fell asleep 2/3 into the movie and I found myself glancing around the room during a few scenes. I would not spend money on this movie as an adult but again for children 8-12 year old this may be great and suitable.

This is a fine movie.  Reasonable adaptation of the Disney classic.  An intermediate number of changes from the cartoon making it somewhat more serious, but not inappropriate for a family.  Great job with all the green-screen work.

My only real issue with this is the voice acting.  It's not B grade or anything but they appear to have gone for very big name actors instead of actors that specialize in interesting voices.  Example: Scarlett Johansson.  Great actress, but not particularly noted for having an interesting voice.  And it really showed.  I don't think her voice worked well with the animation, nor was it very interesting.  Same thing with Bill Murray.  I think his visual acting is what makes him great, not his voice.  He was better, but by no means special.

Anyway, good movie and I recommend it.

I can't imagine a more horrible movie out of the kids movies I've watched recently. No one in the family liked it and I wish I could get my money back. The best part of the movie is the amazing CGI.

The star character of the movie (so the one we're watching and paying attention to for the length of this feature), a kid supposedly raised in the jungle, acts like a dimwit kid that might've be raised by very passive parents then thrown in the jungle for a few days. This dichotomy draws itself through the movie and causes one annoyance after another.

You want a fun, well-written movie for the kids AND adults? Check out Zootopia. You watched that already? Watch it again. That's how bad this movie is. If my kids didn't have toys to distract them mid movie they'd probably happily go to bed instead.

I was pleased to see how much of the Kipling 'magic' and story line that the movie managed to capture.  Animation and live action filming have truly advanced to a remarkable level.  Kipling wrote of the jungle and its harsh ways, but in a manner that has captured the imaginations of countless children since it was first published and this rendition by Disney is a superior effort at bringing his story to the screen.  The story, whether the original as inked by Kipling or this movie version, is not all sweetness and light, there is darkness, terror, and loss of life, but it is handled very well and I think the movie is, overall, a grand effort.

Jon Favreau (Stark Industries "forehead of security" - Iron Man 3) is a great director. If you watch the extras, you will see how he was very hands on with Neel Sethi and how he tried to stay true to the cartoon as much as possible.

Visually very well done. Really missed the point of Kipling's story though, to say nothing of taking some extreme liberties with the books. There was no real plot; most of the story, Mowgli is functionally an item that gets passed from hand to hand (or paw to paw). In Kipling's story, Mowgli succeeds because he embraces both of the worlds he lives in: that of the wolves and that of Man. Here, he has to reject one and embrace the other, setting the entire jungle on fire along the way. Overall, I found it disappointing.

As far as movies go, this is one that is beautifully done with its special effects and landscapes.  The animals look as real as I have seen in any movie to date, well except for the talking part of course. Having been familiar with the remakes and the original book, there are no surprises here for me and I thought the story was done well, although not quite the same as the original story that I remember.  I as an adult didn't find this to be as entertaining as other Disney based family movies but the original Jungle Book has never been one of my favorites to begin with.  I can see how children will find this fun and entertaining though and although I don't see it as a favorite movie for me personally, I did find it entertaining and fun to watch, just for the beautifully done effects alone.  I did find the singing moments a bit annoying and distracting to the movie, especially with Walkens singing in the second half of the movie.

It is worth watching for the CGI alone but for those you like the classic story, this may fall a bit short in that respect.

Jaw-dropping from beginning to end. As a lover of the original cartoon and its "I'm the king of the swingers" and "Bear Necessities" and the initiation as a child to what true friendship actually looks like, I found  myself watching this live action version like I was watching the story for the first time. All the while, remembering each moment from the cartoon and praying and hoping that they'd recreate it.

The voice acting is top notch and the beautiful creations of the characters and animals could have so easily been a distraction and never was. Scarlett Johansson's Kaa was a highlight for me but Idris Elba's Shere Kahn was off the chain brilliant. The danger that his voice and the brilliant CGI work gets across to the audience makes the film. Nothing makes a great film like a great villain and this may be one of the best film villains of all time.

This movie is an instant classic on top of a prior classic and it will ensure that the love of this story will continue for ages. There's power in numbers, there's power in bravery and there's power in friendship. Grab the 3d version from the U.K. and immerse yourself in this gem of a film.

I had this on my Amazon wish list and gave into temptation at the grocery store and bought it there.  I agree with people who have said they're glad they rented it before buying.  Wish I had done the same.  While this rendition is much closer to Kipling's Jungle Book which I loved as a kid, I definitely would not show this movie to children.  I admired the animation.  That's about the only good thing I can say about it.  Mowgli's acting was more like a kid in a grammar school stage play.  The scenes with King Louie were especially too intense for kids, as was the tiger's death scene.  As an adult, I found it uninteresting and a bit dismal to watch all the way through even one time,  and I'll go back to the original animated version if I want to watch it again.  You may have a different opinion after watching it, but I would definitely advise renting it first.

Just received my version of the movie from amazon.uk and it plays just fine on my player. The disc itself is marked with the A, B, C region logo they use, meaning all regions.

Side note:
I find it hard to believe that the UK market sells more 3D blu rays than the entire United States.  It appears that Disney may be pushing to end the market of 3d here in the states. Without sufficient choices of content to help the market grow, there is no other place for it to go but in demise.
For instance, imagine buying Avatar in 3d when it first was released.  There were no other movies available.  Why in the world would anyone purchase a 3d tv and player to play just one movie? The industry has been waiting for the demand without offering supply ---that's just insane.

I want to start off by saying I am not a Jungle Book purist, but I am a fan of the book and I don't feel that any adaptation has been THE ONE yet. That said I loved this movie! It was fun, the world was vibrant and lush and it felt alive and ancient, the voice acting was phenomenal, Neel Sethi did a great job as Mowgli (Even if he did shout his lines worse than Dora and Diego combined), and I loved the edginess they added to the film.

But this is the internet and I am a critic so it can't be all sunshine and rainbows. The few things that don't work are Scarlett Johansson's Kaa and Giancarlo Esposito's Akela. Both of these characters feel underdeveloped. Also the message of the film is muddled.

Kaa is only there to provide flashback exposition. In the books Kaa is all over the place assisting Mowgli and friends (and trying to eat him) Heck even the Jason Scott Lee version had him as a fearsome foe, in this she appears gives some exposition and then fight Baloo off screen. Seems like a waste of an A-list actress.

Akela, likewise doesn't have a lot of screen time. In the books he is Mowgli's great defender, Shere Kahn needs a whole pack of young wolves to try to depose him and his connection to Mowgli is so strong that when he eventually dies it is the driving force for Mowgli to leave the jungle for good. In the film he isn't given enough interactions with Mowgli to form a strong connection,and thus the audience as an extension of Mowgli, we miss out on what could've been a strong paternal character.

Lastly the message of the film seems to warn of the dangers of man's use of fire and the animals fear of it's destructive power...but like in the 1967 version it is used and the destruction is kinda glossed over and there is no consequence to Mowgli for using it.  I feel like his use of the Red Flower is the final litchpin in seperating him from his jungle brethren and transitioning him to humanity...but in this it is a means to an end and really nothing is learned from it. Also there is one throw away line by Lupita Nyong'o's Raksha that seems to hint at Shere Khan breaking the law of the jungle by Killing for pleasure but this is not really fleshed out.

The bottom line is this is a fun movie with lots of heart. The CGI is incredible, the actors are amazing, and the world is teeming with life. It's not a perfect adaptation but it's a helluva tale to spin.

Lets face it, the name Disney on nearly any movie means quality and something that children will flock to. And when you take a well-known Disney film and remake it the odds are in your favor that it will be a hit. You would have to seriously mess things up for it to fail. Thankfully director Jon Favreau didn't do that and has turned in a well done reworking of the classic animated Disney film THE JUNGLE BOOK.

Based in the novel by Rudyard Kipling both versions have strayed a bit from the original source. If youve ever tried to read Kipling youll understand why and give them a pass on this. While the story structure and deep rooted tale remain, just how it is told changes. And while the original Disney film was standard cell animation, this time around we are blessed with the most amazing computer animation there is to offer.

The story itself revolves around a young boy, a human, named Mowgli (Neel Sethi) who was found in the forest of India, taken to a pack of wolves to be raised by his now guardian a black panther named Bagheera (the voice of Ben Kingsley) and who now faces a new danger. With a dry spell in the area a water truce is called among the animals with none allowed to kill another during this draught.

But as they all gather around the nearest watering hole they are surprised by the appearance of Shere Khan (the voice of Idris Elba), a man killing tiger scarred by his last encounter with a human, a human who happened to be Mowglis father. Shere Khan follows the pact for the water truce but warns the animals that when the waters rise once again he will return for the boy.

As the weather changes and the waters rise the wolf pack discusses what they should do about Mowgli. It is Mowgli himself who decides he must leave. Bagheera agrees and so begins the trek of these two to take Mowgli back to the land of men. Adventures follow the pair beginning with an attack by Shere Khan resulting in a slim escape by Mowgli.

Separated from Bagheera Mowgli soon makes friends with a conniving bear named Baloo (the voice of Bill Murray) who enlists his help in bringing down a number of honey combs. When Bagheera shows he scolds the pair and starts the journey with Mowgli again only to have him taken away by a group of monkeys led by King Louie (the voice of Christopher Walken) who wants Mowgli to show him the secret of mans red flower aka fire.

The story carries on and eventually a resolution to the conflict of Shere Khan and Mowgli will bring about the end of the film. That Mowglis friends all become involved is a given. But will they be willing to lay down their lives for this man-cub? Will they consider him the boy theyve loved all these years or will they see him as a growing young man who will present danger to their world?

The movie is a fantastic combination of story and technology that work hand in hand to present the tale in the best way possible. Rather than shoot in an actual jungle the entire production was shot on sound stages equipped with blue screens meaning that while the entire movie takes place in a jungle they were never once in an actual jungle. Not only are the characters computer animated characters but the entire setting is done this way. To combine all of these together is a near impossible task, especially when it comes to the use of shadows. And yet they did it and did it well.

Not only are we presented with this grand vision we also find ourselves wrapped up in this coming of age story about Mowgli. So many things could have gone wrong. The actor playing Mowgli could have been terrible. The animation could have been off. The voice actors could have been the worst choices possible. Instead the right combination of elements comes together here for a jewel of a movie to be added to the Disney crown.

It should also be noted that this film is less of a musical effort than the original. But never fear because at least two songs do appear, the main two that could have spelled disaster had they not been included. Yes The Bear Necessities and I Wanna Be Like You are both hear. Plan on hearing your children singing the songs around the house for the next few weeks.

This is one of those films that anyone with children need to add to their collection. Disney fans need to do the same. And if you enjoy a well-made and entertaining film then youll want a copy as well. It satisfies on all levels.
Great new version. If you haven't seen it, you need to. Definitely darker than the animated version, but done very well.

The Jungle Book, one of Disney's ultimate classics, it has great characters, an awesome story and terrific animation. I'll admit it, I adore Disney movies, I could never choose just one Disney movie as my favorite, I love them all for so many different reasons. The Jungle Book is one of my fav's though, after buying the new release on DVD, I realized that I love this movie now more than ever. The reason that I think this movie is so wonderful is because of the characters, they just brought so much life to the story and really made this into a wonderful Disney classic.

Mowgli is found in a basket as a baby in the deep jungles. Bagheera, the panther who discovers the boy, promptly takes him to a wolf who has just had cubs. She raises him along with her own cubs and Mowgli soon becomes well acquainted to jungle life. Mowgli is shown ten years later, visiting the wolves and getting his face licked eagerly when he arrives. That night, when the wolf tribe learns that Shere Khan, a man-eating tiger, has returned to the jungle, they realize that Mowgli must be taken to the man village, to protect him and those around him. Bagheera volunteers to escort him back. They leave that very night, but Mowgli is determined to stay in the jungle and loses Bagheera. Kaa, the hungry python, hypnotizes Mowgli into a deep and peaceful sleep, traps him tightly in his coils, and tries to devour him, but comically fails. The next morning, Mowgli tries to join the elephant patrol. Bagheera finds Mowgli and they argue; Mowgli runs away from Bagheera. The boy soon meets up with the fun-loving bear Baloo, who shows Mowgli the fun of having a care-free life and promises not to take him to the man village. Mowgli now wants to stay in the jungle more than ever. Shere Khan is after Mawgli though and won't rest 'till he kills him.

Seriously, these are some of the most memorable characters in Disney history, we have Baloo, the care free party bear that just wants to have fun and only needs the "bear" necessities of life. Begheera, a panther, that we've all known this kind of person, the one that just wants to get down to business and get as much done as quickly as possible, the party pooper, but deep down still has that heart. And one of Disney's most memorable villains of all time, Shere Khan, voiced by George Sanders, classy, sassy, menacing and vicious, I wouldn't be surprised if he was Scar's inspiration(the lion villain in The Lion King). If you haven't seen The Jungle Book, just buy it, believe me, it's worth the money. It's a classic fun animated film that I will love forever, still to this day I will always sing along to Bear Necessities, it's a good time.
Author: Kristine (kristinedrama14@msn.com) from Chicago, Illinois

Favreau's 'The Jungle Book' is a technically extraordinary and visually pleasing re-telling of the Rudyard Kipling classic, witty, sweet, and well paced.  Most animation is dull or aesthetically off-putting but this is exquisite-- realistic but not slavishly so, and fun.

Even the one dramatic misstep is a fascinating tangent involving an ancient Indian ruin inhabited by a giant (musical) orangutan.

Family entertainment at its best, a film you can watch many times no matter your age.

Meh. That's my overall feeling about this movie. I was so looking forward to it - The Jungle Book (animated) was one of my favorite childhood movies. But instead of feeling like a linked story, cohesive and total, this felt like a series of vignettes. Nothing had any urgency, there was no sense of tension or drama. Characters came and went, never to appear again. Even Shere Khan barely had a significant role.

I'm glad I rented it instead of going with my first instinct and buying it.

Always shakes away the illusion of a great story.  5 stars turned to 3 for constant overuse- like hiding sandpaper in silk.

Only Disney could destroy a perfectly good movie with one song.  The 2016 version of The Jungle Book is such a good movie, a really fine rendition of Kipling's story--until the Gigantopithicus sings.  The song sequence is so out of place, so distracting, so grating, so completely at odds with the tone of the film up to that point, that it ruins the rest of the movie .  Best guess, it was supposed to be a kind of homage to Disney's animated version, but  why anyone would have wanted to do that is beyond comprehension.  Much as I liked the rest of the film, the ruination was so total that I have no intention of ever buying this one.

All of the animals looked like they came straight out of the jungle.  It did not matter to me but I think it was a great idea that they shortened this movie a bit.  I remember taking small children to movies so many years ago and no matter how much they liked the movie, they got antsy about thirty minutes before it was over.  This movie seemed like the perfect length for little ones.  I was super happy with the move and believe they did a great job!

When I was young, I always begged my grandmother to read me stories from  her copy of The Jungle Book by Rudyard Kipling. I wanted to live in the jungle with those talking animals for friends. Walt Disney produced an animated version in 1967 that had music and comedy as the focus. And for the time, it was good.

But, director Jon Favreau's version of The Jungle Book  has just released on Blu-ray and DVD for home viewing - and I have to say - it is absolutely fantastic!

Favreau has employed 'live-action' filming. It is miles beyond that '67 version. You'd swear that the animals were real, yet the only 'real' actor is Mowgli - played by Neel Sethi. (His journey to being cast and his time on set is one of the special features) The all-star cast includes Bill Murray as the voice of Baloo, Sir Ben Kingsley as Bagheera and Lupita Nyongo as the voice of mother wolf Raksha. Scarlett Johansson gives life to Kaa, Giancarlo Esposito  provides the voice of alpha-male wolf Akela, Idris Elba roars as the voice of Shere Khan, and Christopher Walken. These voices were absolutely perfect for each character. I have to say I probably enjoyed Baloo the most.

Favreau has stayed very close to the stories I remember. Even though I knew what would happen, I found myself caught up in the story, crying for the wolves, frightened of Kaa and Shere Khan and protected by Bagheera and Baloo. He's also included music from the '67 version. Walken's King Louie song is priceless. But my fave is Baloo's The Bear Necessities. Again, I can't stress how good the graphics are - check out the trailer below to see for yourself. The bonus features are great, giving you a look at behind the scenes. This new version is a wonderful tribute to Kipling's stories. Just excellent for this viewer.

This is a family film with a few caveats - there is a death and some danger. I'll be sharing the stories and movie with my grandson when he's a few years older. Until then, I am so happy to have this in my DVD library - I can still dream of living in the jungle with talking animals for family!

I have never liked the Jungle Book. It has been one of those movies I've had to watch as a kid and never liked. Sure I liked the songs and had the cassette tape but the movie was never for me. Remakes growing up were not great and I was never interested. I saw the preview for this earlier this year and thought that it looked different, interesting, dark but fun...So I finally after months gave it a try. My family and I set up in the living room and on it went. From the beginning I was hooked! The animals looked so real and the little boy was very likeable. The voices all fit and my favorite was Baloo, Bill Murray. It was such a great movie and I didn't want it to end. It completely changed my views on the Jungle Book and quickly shot up to the top of my favorites list. My kids really liked it as well and my 9 year old son who never sits down long enough to watch a movie stayed the whole time and was extremely interested. This is worth the rent/buy. I bought because we watch it over and over again.

As far as Disney's current penchant for reimagining their classic, animated films in live-action I gotta say "Jungle Book" coulda been way worse but on the other hand it's no "Cinderella" (which was excellent BTW).

The Pros: a child star in Neel Sethi who can not only act but when you consider this is pretty much a one-kid show in front of a green screen you gotta give him props.  The CGI characters are all excellently rendered and the sets gorgeous.  Treats the 1967 film with obvious respect while not coming off as soulless, opportunistic nostalgia.

The Cons:  Who in the hell thought casting Christopher Walken as King Louis was a good idea? I was literally squirming in my seat and wanted desperately to fast forward when he sang "I wanna be like you".  Oh, and not really sure why they morphed King Louis into King Kong... Kipling's book took place in India's precolonial past not the frigg'n Pleistocene.  It's obvioius Hollywood can't get enough of Scarlett Johanssen but as a voice actor she's about as lifeless as a lump of coal (her singing on the other hand...).  And finally what is it with Idris Elba, just being British doesn't automatically make you a shoe-in for Shere Khan but apparently every director in the industry has a hardon for this guy.  Not saying he's a bad actor, just every time you go to the movies these days there he is; I'm surprised they didn't cast him as Mowgli as well... then it could've been The Elba Book... I'm sure the critics would've spazgasmed over that one... probably would've said something like "a fresh and exciting spin on an old classic for a new generation".

Look, I get that Disney movies are high profile but I wish they'd stop with the name dropping already, nobody's impressed... Robin Williams as the genie in Aladdin was an exception not the rule.  Final Analysis: Rent before you buy. :o)

If you're looking to choose between buying the new CGI movie and the fully animated Disney film from '67, I would say the old movie wins hands down in almost every respect.
The original is pretty much a classic Disney film in its usual style (note this wasn't the first Jungle Book either... there was a 1937 film "Elephant Boy" and also a 1942 movie with live actors, but these were not by Disney and with far less on the animal side).

Jungle Book '67 was loaded with clever humour and one-liners, memorable songs, excellent voiceovers and strangely enough imo, the 'actors' in the animated show more range of emotion and facial expression than the new computer animals, even down to Mowgli a real human, who really was one of the better parts of the '16 film.
What's good about the new movie?  Well the special effects are excellent. King Louie was quite amazing, Baloo the bear was humorous, basically Bill Murray in bear form and well rendered... KAA the snake was cool, etc.  Most of the humour was in the backup animals having goofy voices, which is an old standby now in the newer CGI films.  Interestingly enough Jim Henson's famous muppets were brought in to act with the human cast members, though they never even appeared in the film itself this time, which shows how bad things have gotten for puppeteers in the film industry.  Disney also gets credit for not making the new movie basically an 'improved' carbon copy rewrite of their original, there's enough of a difference between the two films to make owning both worth it.
So in short if you're collecting Jungle Books, this is a worthy addition.  If you're choosing, my vote goes for the older version.

I don't generally review movies or music because I know they are larger a thing of personal preference as to whether or not it's enjoyed or hated, but this one I was genuinely disappointed with. I was hoping for a "live action" version of this film. It's one live action person in the character of Mowgli and a bunch of CGI animals that follow him around. The animals are all voiced by great actors and, in that respect, it does save the film to a certain extent. My main complaint is with Neel Sethi (the actor who plays Mowgli). In my opinion, if you are going to put the entire film on the shoulders of a child to carry it, you had better bust your butt to make sure that kid is AMAZING. This kid, not so much. His performance just fell flat and came across as more whiny than courageous and independent. That being said, there are several upsides to this film. While I'm not a fan of using CGI animals in general, they are very well done and the scenery is beautiful. It's overall an ok film but not something I would recommend or buy again.

Before: man-cub grows up, discovers the opposite sex, enters village, presumably raises a family and becomes a productive part of society.  Now: man-cub has a "failure to launch", reclines on his couch... er... tree branch, lives happily ever after doing nothing , all while letting the jungle support him.

There have been a number of adaptations of the Jungle Book, in various mediums including live action and animation. Some of them were very good, while others were less than mediocre. This Jungle Book was, without qualification, the best I've seen. Idris Elba was menacing as Shere Khan, Giancarlo Esposito was a kind and caring father as Akela, Ben Kingsley as Bagheera was an understanding and courageous guide to the wonderful Mowgli, Neel Sethi, and Bill Murray gave Balloo a new layer of humor. This is a movie that the entire family can enjoy. If the book is filmed again, which it probably will be, the producers would need to go a long way to create a version that would be remotely close to this one.

I hate remakes.  I detest reboots even more.  So, I went into this with little expectation that it would arrive anywhere in the neighborhood of being watchable.  I am very proud to report, my cynicism was quickly and easily discredited.  Although, not a fan of the books, this cinematic incarnation that mixes a definitive respect for the source material and homage to Disney's animated classic, delivers a heartfelt, visually stunning, and utterly endearing theatrical journey.  With a remarkable cast, providing truly inspired performances, surprising yet appropriate musical interludes, and breathtaking effects, this live-action retelling kept me riveted to my seat from start to finish.

Not what I was hoping for based on all the rave reviews. Needless to say this doesn't come close to the book or animated movie. Like so many remakes and reboots this new Jungle Book is completely unnecessary. If they tried to do a lot of different things with the material, or stuck closer to the book or something, I could maybe see the need for this but as it is it just doesn't bring enough new things to the table and what it does offer lacks coherence, excitement, and logic.

My main problem with the movie is that everything feels like a setup and there's no real connection to the story or characters. The plot wasn't executed that well, with quite a few generic scenes and issues with tone and pacing. It feels like scenes loosely connected and tied together to make a story and to get everything in there. They seemed to be trying hard to get a few laughs in there, force in some songs, and have things the general crowd will recognize.

*spoilers*

The scene where Shere Khan just walks up to the wolves, kills Akela, and then claims that area for himself is pretty ridiculous. The wolves don't gang up on him, they don't retaliate for him killing one of their pack, they just sit there and let him take the place over. Aren't they supposed to be wolves? They keep talking about "the law of the jungle" and honor and yet they just let a tiger come in and start calling the shots? Strange. And we don't even see how Mowgli grows up with the animals and how they have a connection, he's just there. Then later we get a 3 minute or so flashback showing him as a toddler. His father is killed by Shere Khan and he just walks up to Bagheera and instantly they're best friends. This scene happens after Kaa is introduced and then all of a sudden Baloo steps in to the story, saves the man-cub, and Kaa is forever out of the story. Then Mowgli and Baloo collect honey for a little while and then they're best of friends, they even sing a song which is pretty out of place. Akela is a character no audience could care about and yet his death is treated like a big deal to the characters and a reason to go back and stand up to Shere Khan.

King Louie is introduced by a cowbell and starts singing a very out of place tune. He wants Mowgli to work with him, he refuses and attempts an escape, and so King Louie proceeds to smash down his own home and then presumably gets crushed to death. Hmm. Mowgli gets upset about Akela's death, musters up some courage to face Shere Khan, and runs back to his home. Only it takes him 30 seconds to run back there when this whole time he's been traveling to the man village which was far away. Well that doesn't make sense. But not only that, along the way he accidentally starts a fire and it starts to burn down the forest. A few embers drop to the ground and next thing you know by the time he runs back home, which seems to take only minutes, the entire place is up in flames. So in what time span did that happen exactly? Seems like sloppy writing to me. The pacing is just downright bad. Anyway, all the animals together are no match for Shere Khan (that's gotta be the strongest Tiger that ever lived) and so he chases down Mowgli and finally has his showdown with him, although the final fight is strangely reminiscent of Lion King. It's just more generic and uninspired drama with a serious lack of tension.

There's not a single compelling character in the entire movie and that's a big problem. In the book and animated movie there were characters, but not here. People can talk all they want about the great effects, but effects will only take you so far. The voice acting was neither good nor bad, stars voice the characters but there's no weight behind it. No real reason why there couldn't have just been professional voice actors in there instead of well known actors who act more like special guests, it's very distracting watching these CGI animals being voiced by them. The CGI was good for being CGI but it looks so fake it wouldn't even be proper to call this "live action." Everything looks so clean and computerized, it just looks fake, and it really took me out of it. I enjoyed watching the Blu-ray/DVD combo of The Jungle Book about Mowgli (Neel Sethi) who is the only man cub in the jungle. He wants to be a wolf, but in reality he's not. He is raised by wolves and he feels he has a nice life. Then one day Shere Khan (Idris Elba) threatens Mowglis life. While the wolves argue about whether or not Mowgli should leave for the safety of the pack, Mowgli decides for them and leaves. He ventures out to find the man village. On his way to the man village, he meets many enemies and friends like King Louie (Christopher Walken), Kaa (Scarlett Johansson) and Baloo (Bill Murray).  What will happen next?  Will he make it to the man village?  Does Shere Khan catch him? You just have to watch the movie to find out.

What I liked about the bonus features on the Blu-ray disc is a feature called, The Jungle Book Reimagined which shows ideas for the remake of The Jungle Book and Neel Sethis experience while acting on the set. This shows the relationship between Neel and the director. There is also a bonus audio commentary feature from the director, Jon Favreau, which is great because you get to hear what he was thinking when making the movie. Another added bonus allows you to go to the scene selection and select the scene you want, plus there is a setup feature so you can insert your own settings. There is also a DVD version included and a download code to download a digital copy if you would prefer to use that versus the discs.

What I like about this movie are the CGIs which are so realistic that you think the sets are real because they are so incredibly detailed. The animals look realistic as well and the backgrounds are very intricate.  But, as I learned in the Blu-ray feature I am Mowgli, it shows that it was all done on green screen, which makes this film more incredible because most of it isn't real!  The voice acting is superb.  Idris Elba, Scarlett Johansson, Bill Murray, Christopher Walken and many others truly bring the animals to life with their outstanding voice over work. Speaking about Christopher Walken, another bonus feature is King Louies Temple Layer by Layer.  It shows you how the I Wanna Be Like You scene was created. It is very interesting to watch how the orchestra, Christopher Walken, the storyboard and green screens worked together to make that sequence.  Finally, the music is superb and adds so much more energy and excitement to the movie. It just makes the scenes more interesting than they would be without such compelling music.

What you should know about this film is that there are many intense scenes. Even I jumped out of my seat a few times. This isn't a movie for children below age 9 and is definitely a know your kid type of movie. I also didn't like how King Louie doesnt look as friendly as in the original movie. Aside from that, this movie is truly outstanding entertainment.

I recommend this film to kids ages 9 to 18.  People who like action, adventure and comedy movies will surely enjoy this. It does have intense scenes and will make you jump but I give it 4 out of 5 stars and love all the bonus features on the DVD/Blu-ray/Digital HD which is available

I was looking forward to this version of the classic Kipling tale, and I think I may have liked it better if I hadn't seen the original Disney version - which this film tried to emulate, but managed to miss the mark.

For example the character voices were far better in the original version - Sebastian Cabot, Phil Harris and particularly Sterling Holloway blew away the actor voices in this film version. The original film had more songs as well, and they were more naturally part of the movie (and performed better to boot). The only actor's voice performance that rivaled the original film was Christopher Walken as King Louie.

There is some amazingly detailed CGI in this film, but CGI does not make a movie. The first Disney film with it's hand drawn animation was a lot more fun because the storyline moved along better, and that is what makes a good film. If you're going to remake something, make it better - don't just toss in new technology and miss out on all the fun!

Disney brings its venerable technique of mixing live and animated forms to full fruition in The Jungle Book, a rollicking remake of the 1967 classic thats surprisingly fun, if ecologically messy.

Directed by Jon Favreau (Iron Man, Chef) with reverence for the cartoon and more of a nod to Rudyard Kiplings original 1896 fable, The Jungle Book is nearly nonstop action for long stretches as young Mowgli is chased, hypnotized, bamboozled and kidnapped by a variety of unlikely jungle denizens.  Conscientious and eco-minded adults will struggle for the actual moral to it all; Kiplings original story drew parallels between mans dominion over nature and Britains imperial ambitions over most of the Third World.  Disneys animated film glossed over all that.  Favreau and writer Justin Marks ditch most of the songs in favor of some utopian vision of animals peacefully coexisting (we never see the carnivores consume meat) with a young man-cub who can speak their language, despite the fact that he will grow into the thing they fear most.  Most controversially, they completely change the ending of the original, which further confuses the issues.  But in an age where Disneys animated films (Zootopia) deftly wrestle with deeper themes of the nature of animals and humans, the live action films seem freer to just have some fun.

As Mowgli, newcomer Neel Sethi is a delight; gleefully nave but shrewd and resourceful.  His performance is especially noteworthy in that hes the only actual human; he had to act to puppets, prompts and a room of green screen.  Bill Murray embodies Mowglis bear friend Baloo with mirth and sweetness, and Ben Kingsley finds the right authoritarian note as his protector, the panther Bagheera.  But its Idris Elbas terrifying scarred tiger Shere Khan that steals the show, made all the scarier because he just might be right about the threat of man.

Christopher Walkens take on King Louie is a bit mystifyingthe oversized orangutan (or, in this version, gigantopithecus) could easily be called King Kong for his dinosaur-sized girth.  He and Kaa, the snake (a beguiling Scarlett Johansson in an all-too brief cameo) are monstrously overlarge.  We first encounter Louie by hearing his raspy voice emanate from the shadows of his temple, surrounded by offerings of fruit and treasure, like Marlon Brandos Colonel Kurtz in Apocalypse Now, imploring Mowgli to support his twisted and self-deluded desire to learn to make fire (the red flower).  Disney added the character of King Louie to the original as a weird nod to the hippie/jazz/beatnik culture.  When Walken breaks into his signature song, I Wanna Be Like You, its fraught with menace.  Ironically, in a fable of mostly smart animals who can all communicate with each other, Louie is the only one who wants to break free of the Law of the Jungle and evolve.

This is the rare movie for which Id highly recommend a 3D viewing; youll be immersed in a digital jungle with surreal landscapes that are the stuff of dreams and nightmares; a run through tangles of vines, massively entwined tree branches, raging floods and wildebeest stampedes, and claws length from one vengeful and nasty tiger.

Eco-reality and moral ambiguity aside, this is a fun, mercifully brief romp in a fantasy world that delivers with staggering visuals and warm humor.

THE KID FACTOR:  Pretty intense in some scenes, and a lot of these characters will give kids nightmares.
SURPRISES:  Garry Shandlings last film role; thats his voice as Ikki the Porcupine

Favreau did a stellar job on this remake!  The Jungle Book has always been one of my favorite Disney films, and I have fond childhood memories of these characters.  I was most excited to see how a "real-life" adaptation would turn out!

A few points of interest:

*Some of the storyline does change from the original, so it is fresh in that way.

*There are preludes to the introduction of some of the characters we love, and there is a bit of suspense awaiting them.

*I found the score to be fascinating. This film was synonymous with certain songs; of those, only one was fully reminiscent of its predecessor.  The others were either reworked some, or served as background orchestral/theatrical numbers.  All were recognizable though, and I thought they were just beautifully done.  Even with new scenery, nostalgia rings strong in undertones.  Fantastic.

*One of my favorite scenes is when the baby elephant is first shown.  The subtle slow shot was a small touch that left a big impact.

*Special affects were on point.

*Kaa's infamous hypnotizing was tweaked in a significant way for this plot line.

*The bees DO sting.  The bees always sting.  Lol.

This wasn't a bad remake of a classic movie based on an even older book.  It's marketed as live action, but really the only non animated character is Mowgli, the man cub.  Every other character is still animated, although granted they look a lot more realistic than they ever did before.  Technology for the human in a cartoon has certainly come a long way since Who Framed Roger Rabbit.  The storyline is pretty basic, a kid who has been raised by wolves after a panther told them to, has been targeted by a tiger who doesn't like his kind (man) and wants him dead once the truce brought on by a drought where no animals can kill each other is brought to an end by rain.  This truce seemed a bit odd to me, I mean what do all the carnivores eat during this time? I mean Mowgli has baby puppy brothers and sisters that need nourishment to grow, not to mention food to stay alive. It seems odd no animals are insulted that he is using the shell of a dead turtle to scoop water. But that's the scenario we have here, of course it rains, Mowgli is taken away by the panther for his own safety but the panther is attacked on route to the human village.  Mowgli flees on the back of a buffalo, the Tiger goes back to the wolves and kills the alpha knowing word will get to Mowgli and he'll return for vengeance where he can be killed.  Mowgli encounters a giant snake, a  bear, some monkeys, a King Kong sized orangutan, and other animals along the way who either try to kill him or use him for their own gains.

The movie does involve the death of some animals but since it's a kids movie it happens off screen or masked by smoke or something each time.  It doesn't have constant interruptions of songs like the original cartoon version, but there still is one or two.  The one by Christopher Walken didn't really fit into the flow of what was happening at the time and seemed to be there simply because it was in the all animated earlier film.  The repeated words at the end of each sentence was actually quite annoying as it was out of tune.

But overall The Jungle Book isn't a bad movie.  The closing credits are visually quite interesting with the animation happening on top of the pages of the book, then you've got a James Bond style silhouette thing happening which was quite well done, in fact the whole closing credits were.  Mowgli acts like a human boy who has lived with humans rather than a boy raised by canines but other than that, it's a fairly decent film.

So same with home viewing, we saw it in 3D in theater, now we want add that mini version of 3D to our home collection. So why Disney doesn't release that in 3D is what I don't understand!!?!! It's like going from blu ray down to standard format.
